p: Computed tomography (CT) can be considered as an essential supplemental investigative tool for the detection of COVID-19 pneumonia in this pandemic context. In severe cases, CT plays an important role in identifying viral lung infection, examining the nature and extent of pulmonary lesions, and scrutinizing the disease severity [ 63]. Known features of COVID-19 on initial CT consist of bilateral multilobar with an usual of three lung segments, ground-glass opacification (GGO) with a peripheral or posterior distribution, principally in the lower lobes and some times inside the right middle lobe. Consolidative opacities superimposed on GGO may be reported in a few elderly population. Other uncommon findings include septal thickening, bronchiectasis, pleural thickening, and subpleural involvement, which are rarely reported in the later stages of the disease [ 64]. The imaging pattern readily change over a short period of time [ 65].
